Nikolas Hulewsky (07:06.402)

But then these innovative products start popping up and they kind of start stealing some of your market share. And the innovator's dilemma is, do we continue to double down on this core product and make little changes to it, little optimizations over time just to make the product better or


Do we embrace this new innovation and start putting out products that effectively will cannibalize the golden goose that we've had over a period of time? And there's lots of examples over time. Clayton Christensen first, I think, coined this phrase. If you read the book, Good to Great or any of his other works, he was a famous Harvard professor. But that's kind of what Google's going through right now. And it's so weird because you would think Google's the best position to own the AI race. They've got

What if instead of going to Google Drive or going to your Gmail and then going outside of it to search, you used Gemini to search for those things? They would continue to own the quote unquote search market or the AI market. But that that product that they once had would just kind of be gone.
